data.title: Markdown Show Source With Tabs Sometimes Switches To Previous File
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6 Insiders
##### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open two markdown files side by side
2. Click on the left one
3. Now click on the right one.
4. Run markdown show source
##### Expected

The current document stays active since it already is the source.
##### Actual

The editor switches back to the file in the first tab.

![sep-27-2016 15-45-23](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12821956/18894764/b031cedc-84c9-11e6-8bee-78152b0620b4.gif)

If you click on two lines in the right editor or make any edits, show source does the correct thing.

data.title: Empty workspace: keep UI state and reopen files
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.3
- OS Version: Windows 10 Version: 1607

**Scenario:** Open files from different directories (not using the "open folder" function) by either dragging them into the editor or using Open File. Close VSC, reopen it.
**Desired Behaviour:** All previously opened files are reopened with the same view/caret position.
**Actual Behaviour:** VSC is blank when opened

I know this feature exists for "Open Folder" but that's not what I want as I rarely open files this way, normally the files span completely different directories (or even machines).

Discussed further in this thread #101 (but a separate issue).

data.title: Markdown Should Highlight ! for Images
data.body:
For a markdown file like this:

``` md
text ![img](imgpath) text
```

The `!` should also be highlighted, probably the same as the `[`.

![screen shot 2016-09-27 at 3 33 01 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12821956/18894414/b816d55e-84c7-11e6-99fc-a98b040264d7.png)

The `!` is currently styled the same as normal text.

data.title: Auto format on save doesn't work when quitting VS Code (and saving changes)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Insiders
- OS Version: Mac OS X El Capitan

![problem - quit doesnt save](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11839736/18894404/9ded7872-84c7-11e6-9b04-f12a25f3160d.gif)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Have a file with unformatted code in a dirty state
2. Try to quit VS Code
3. Click save changes when prompted
4. Open VS Code and the previous file that had unformatted code.

Note that the code is still unformatted.

data.title: Next/Prev Group should not create new group
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.0
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.6

Currently if you have group 1 & 2 and is on 2, `Go -> Switch Group -> Next Group` will create Group 3. Instead it should go to group 1.

If you have group 1, 2 & 3 and focus is on 3, `Go -> Switch Group -> Next Group` will do nothing. It should go to group 1, too.

data.title: Auto format after saving a non-open tab corrupts undo history for it
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Insiders
- OS Version: Mac OSX El Capitan

Regarding test plan item #12639 

Steps to Reproduce:

![problem-focuslostsave-undostack](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11839736/18894174/5d9c4de4-84c6-11e6-9a7d-d3eba35f79fd.gif)
1. Have some unformatted code in a file that is in a dirty state
2. Open a different tab in that same editor group so that the unsaved tab that has dirty code is not present.
3. Use the "Save All" button in the Explorer
4. Reopen that tab and try to undo your changes (does not undo the auto format correctly).

Note that you can undo the changes in all other cases (tab not focused, tab active), but if the tab is not open at the time, the undo history seems to get messed up.

data.title: Support standard tab navigation key shortcuts on macOS
data.body:
macOS has OS wide shortcuts for navigating to the previous/next tab of:

> cmd+shift+[
> cmd+shift+]

Surprised to see that these don't work in VSCode. This was mentioned in #9333 but implemented as API commands and #8234 comes close but neither get all the way to making it standard for macOS or even making it an option for keybindings.json (as far as I can tell). Would be great for this to be supported.

data.title: TextDocumentSaveReason literals
data.body:
Testing #12640

Currently: Explicit, Auto, FocusOut

'Explicit' is not very explicit about its meaning, maybe 'Manual' would be?

'FocusOut' is automatic too, maybe 'Auto' should be 'Delay'?

data.title: Markdown Preview View Has Incorrect Size With Zooming
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6 Insiders
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open markdown preview of document
2. Zoom in or out

![sep-27-2016 14-25-20](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12821956/18892404/3f734ece-84be-11e6-80b1-5e4792203df0.gif)

When zooming in, the markdown preview pane shrinks in the editor window (see location of scrollbars). When zooming out, the preview document grows beyond the editor window and the scroll bars are hidden.

data.title: Markdown Incorrect Colorization of Block Quotes Containing Html
data.body:
Markdown file: ``` md > start
bold text
> second **line** . >
bold text
> second **line** . >
bold text
more text > second **line** . > start
bold text
more text > second **line** . >
bold text
more text > second **line** . > bold text > second **line** . > start bold text > second **line** . > bold text more text > second **line** ``` Results in the following: ![screen shot 2016-09-27 at 2 04 09 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12821956/18891702/517c7ecc-84bb-11e6-9344-13f29e5198d7.png) These should all have roughly the same colorization - For block elements that open the line, such as `
`, the highlighting of the second line is incorrect. - For inline elements, if it is the only element on the line, the highlighting of the second line is also incorrect.

data.title: Markdown Incorrect Colorization of Fenced Code Blocks Inside of Block Quotes
data.body:
For a markdown file like this:

`````` ms
> ```js
> 
> ```

**Blue Bold** white
``````

The colorization is incorrect. Depending on what language is targeted, the colorization can break out of the code block entirely:

![screen shot 2016-09-27 at 1 54 36 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12821956/18891457/28691f28-84ba-11e6-8560-89ea0b95f0bc.png)
![screen shot 2016-09-27 at 1 54 31 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12821956/18891458/286a3cbe-84ba-11e6-90fc-380caf73ab30.png)

Here's what things should look like: 

![screen shot 2016-09-27 at 1 54 47 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12821956/18891456/284d7a84-84ba-11e6-9647-7d5e6d13f5a8.png)

The problem is that that block quote opening `>` are included as part of the fenced code block content. This causes some language colorizers to freak-out and highlight the entire rest of the file.

data.title: Output panel grabs focus when tsc is restarted
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.6.0-insider (f62883f07422cae4b53c2a185b105091460a0a85, 2016-09-27T12:46:15.113Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.6.0

Related to #12814

I've had the integrated terminal open when I copied a .ts file in the workspace and that triggered a restart of tsc. At that point the Output panel grabed focus which is unexpected since I loose my context.

data.title: Find and Replace: "Find in selection" includes current line of multi-line selection

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.3
- OS Version: Windows 10.0.14393

If your selection spans multiple lines, and the cursor rests at col 1 of the last line, this last line will be included in the selection even if no characters on that line were _actually_ selected.
## Steps to Reproduce:
1. Make sure you have content on every line you test these instructions against
2. Place your cursor at the front of a line (Col 1)
3. How Shift and press down to select multiple lines
4. After a few lines stop pressing down (your cursor should still be at Col 1)
5. Press Ctrl+H to open Find and Replace
6. Click "Find in selection" on the small control panel that opened previously
7. You'll see that the line where the cursor rests is included in the selection

![unintended selection expansion](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1189638/18891219/2308bd3c-84b9-11e6-9185-17d3d2ae2951.gif)
## Expected result:

I expect that a line, without any selection visibly applied to it, does not result in the entire line being included in the selection.
## Steps to workaround:

Press the left arrow key after selecting all your lines for the cursor to be placed at the end of the previous line.

data.title: Asyncawait + Fibers = extension errors
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.2
- OS Version: 10.10.5

I created a new extension using `asyncawait` which utilizes `node-fibers`:

```
"dependencies": {
    "asyncawait": "^1.0.6",
    "bluebird": "^3.4.6",
    "copy-paste": "^1.3.0",
    "open": "0.0.5",
    "request": "^2.74.0"
  }
```

```
'use strict';

const vscode = require('vscode');
const request = require('request');
const copyPaste = require('copy-paste');
const open = require('open');
const async = require('asyncawait/async');
const await = require('asyncawait/await');
const Promise = require('bluebird');
```

I get the following error when starting up my extension:

```
Activating extension `MyLaptop.vscode-myextension` failed: `/Users/user1/Repos/vscode-myextension/node_modules/fibers/bin/darwin-x64-v8-4.9/fibers.node` is missing. Try reinstalling `node-fibers`?.
Activating extension `MyLaptop.vscode-myextension` failed:  `/Users/user1/Repos/vscode-myextension/node_modules/fibers/bin/darwin-x64-v8-4.9/fibers.node` is missing. Try reinstalling `node-fibers`?
Here is the error stack:  Error: `/Users/user1/Repos/vscode-myextension/node_modules/fibers/bin/darwin-x64-v8-4.9/fibers.node` is missing. Try reinstalling `node-fibers`?
    at Object.<anonymous> (/Users/user1/Repos/vscode-myextension/node_modules/fibers/fibers.js:16:8)
    at Module._compile (module.js:413:34)
    at Object.Module._extensions..js (module.js:422:10)
    at Module.load (module.js:357:32)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:314:12)
    at Function.L.I.n._load (/Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/vs/workbench/node/extensionHostProcess.js:12:25921)
    at Module.require (module.js:367:17)
    at require (internal/module.js:16:19)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/Users/user1/Repos/vscode-myextension/node_modules/asyncawait/src/fibers.js:1:92)
    at Module._compile (module.js:413:34)
```

I reinstalled `node-fibers` but continued to get the same errors. I know there were some issues a while back (#1556) and I'm not sure if this is related or not. I don't see any issues related to `node-fibers`. Any clues?

Also, I'm using just plain JS. Not TypeScript for the extension.

data.title: vscode.previewHtml appears to modify (or restrict) HTML/Javascript of the passed URI
"Check For Update" menu item disappears when "update.channel" is configured to "none" (macOS Sierra)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.3
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12

Steps to Reproduce:
1. in "User Settings" set parameter "update.channel" to "none"
2. restart VSCode
3. check main menu "Code", item listed as "Check For Update" will be hidden

It seems that when you opt out of VS Code auto-updates there is no ability to check for updates manually, and I think there should be ability to check for updates manually.

Do not know is it bug or "feature"😏

data.title: In-product release notes design issues
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.5.0 (f62883f07422cae4b53c2a185b105091460a0a85, 2016-09-27T13:07:11.616Z)

#12520

Since this will become one of the main ways users will consume release notes it should look good.
- No padding on page

- `kb()` annotations are not resolved

- No syntax highlighting

data.title: Format-on-type: Cursor on wrong side of edit
Spurious "No task to execute found" info
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.6.0-insider (f62883f07422cae4b53c2a185b105091460a0a85, 2016-09-27T12:46:15.113Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.6.0

Not sure how to reproduce. Happened twice while testing #12633. The Output panel with the Tasks channel would open and an info message box saying "No task to execute found" (or similar) would briefly show.

I was running tsc -w as a task and that process and its output in the Output panel have disappeared. So maybe tsc just hung up? The message should say so then and the Output panel should still show its output I'd expect.

data.title: Unclear how to delete a config value using WorkspaceConfiguration.update
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.6.0 (f62883f07422cae4b53c2a185b105091460a0a85, 2016-09-27T13:07:11.616Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-38-generic, Ubuntu 16.04
#12614

I tried this but it set it to `null`:

``` js
vscode.workspace.getConfiguration().update('terminal.integrated.cursorBlinking', undefined, true);
```

Not sure how to do it, I was expecting a `WorkspaceConfiguration.delete(key: string)` API?

data.title: WorkspaceConfiguration.update should warn when setting invalid values
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.6.0-insider (f62883f07422cae4b53c2a185b105091460a0a85, 2016-09-27T13:07:11.616Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-38-generic, Ubuntu 16.04
#12614

Steps to Reproduce:

The following does nothing and doesn't warn:

``` js
vscode.workspace.getConfiguration().update('terminal.integrated', false, true)
```

At the least I would expect a console message.

data.title: Scrolling terminal keyboard shortcuts not working on MacOS
data.body:
Testing #12685.
- VSCode Version: 1.6.0 insiders
- OS Version: MacOs

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a terminal
2. execute command with multipage output
3. use Command+ArrowUp to scroll a single line up
   -> `9A` is printed to the console but no scrolling

Executing the command from the command palette works as expected.

Same for Scrolling a line down, or scrolling page wise.
